conversation.text: Boil a pot of water and then gently add the pig ears to boil for 5 minutes.
evidence: Fill a pot of water with 1 litre (2.1 US pt) of water then bring it to boil over a high heat

conversation.text: What do I do after 5 minutes?
Put the ears in a different pot, cover with water, then add flavorings and spices.
evidence: Add the ears and other ingredients into another pot
Then, add 60 milliliters (2 fl oz) (4 tbsp) of rice wine, 45 milliliters (1.5 fl oz) (3 tbsp) of soy sauce, 30 grams (2 tbsp) of sugar, 1 star anise, and 1 cinnamon stick into the pot with the ears

conversation.text: What temperature water should I use?
This is not specified.
What spices should I put in then?
Add rice wine, soy sauce, sugar, star anise, and a cinnamon stick
evidence: 60 milliliters (2 fl oz) (4 tbsp) of rice wine, 45 milliliters (1.5 fl oz) (3 tbsp) of soy sauce
30 grams (2 tbsp) of sugar, 1 star anise, and 1 cinnamon stick

conversation.text: What do I do after this?
Cook the pig ears for 2.5 hours and keep them submerged
evidence: Bring the heat down to a gentle simmer and let the mix cook for 2.5 hours

conversation.text: What do I do after that?
Have the ears changed color or are they soft enough?
evidence: You can tell if the ears are done by their rich red-brown color or by piercing the flesh with a chopstic

conversation.text: What color should they be?
They should be a rich red-brown color and soft enough to be pierced by a chopstick.
What is the next step?
Remove them from the pot and refrigerate them for 1-2 hours. Are they completely solid and chilled yet?
evidence: Let the ears cool, then refrigerate them for 1-2 hours

conversation.text: They are ready now. What's next?
Slice the ears thinly and serve cold. Do you have other appetizers to serve them with?
evidence: Slice the pig ears into thin slivers

conversation.text: Yes, I do! Is it done then?
Yes, the recipe is finished.
evidence: Once you've finished stacking the slivers, serve the dish cold

conversation.text: Thank you for the help!

recipe.title: How to Make Chinese-Style Pig Ears

procedure.summary: Heat a pot of water to boil the ears for 5 minutes.
procedure.description: Fill a pot of water with 1 litre (2.1 US pt) of water then bring it to boil over a high heat. Once the water has started to boil, slowly lower the pig ears into the pot. Let them boil for 5 minutes so that any impurities can be safely removed.

procedure.summary: Add the ears and other ingredients into another pot.
procedure.description: Remove the pig's ears from the boiling water and place them into a separate pot. Add enough water to cover the ears. Then, add 60 milliliters (2  fl oz) (4 tbsp) of rice wine, 45 milliliters (1.5  fl oz) (3 tbsp) of soy sauce, 30 grams (2 tbsp) of sugar, 1 star anise, and 1 cinnamon stick into the pot with the ears.

Bring the heat down to a gentle simmer and let the mix cook for 2.5 hours checking every so often that the ears are still submerged. You can tell if the ears are done by their rich red-brown color or by piercing the flesh with a chopstick. If the chopstick goes through easily, they're ready. The Chinese-style syrup left over can be used for a side dish to give it a Chinese flavor.

procedure.summary: Let the ears cool, then refrigerate them for 1-2 hours.
procedure.description: With a pair of tongs, remove the pig ears from the pot and lay them on a chopping board. Allow them to cool to room temperature, then refrigerate them for 1-2 hours until they are completely solid and chilled.

procedure.summary: Slice the ears and serve them.
procedure.description: Remove the ears from the fridge and put them on a chopping board. Slice the pig ears into thin slivers then organise the slivers on a plate so that the wafers stack on top of each other. Once you've finished stacking the slivers, serve the dish cold. This dish is best eaten cold and works as a tasty accompaniment to the host of other cold Chinese appetizers.
